Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Fairfield REU in Mathematics and Computational Science
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Fairfield University Research Experiences for Undergraduates Program in Mathematics and Computational Science is an eight-week summer program designed to engage talented undergraduates in original mathematics and computing research, beyond the college curriculum. The program hosts nine students per summer, providing on-campus housing and student stipends. The participants spend their time working and learning in small groups, with each group in close consultation with an individual Fairfield University faculty mentor on research topics drawn from the mentor's field of expertise.

The principal goal of the program is to prepare the participants for research-based scientific careers, and to engender in each student a deep understanding not only of the importance of individual scientific research, but also of the broader context of collaboration into which that research fits. This is achieved by providing the students with the experience of a research cohort. This collaborative research environment - students working with faculty and with each other - also allows for the general advancement of the mathematics and computing disciplines, and fosters the continuing scholarly and pedagogical development of all the academic professionals involved.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Fairfield Unviersity REU Program in Mathematics and Computational Science is an immersive summer science program designed to introduce qualified undergraduates to, and mentor them through, the process of sophisticated mathematical research. Over the course of the three summers (2014-2016) covered under our NSF grant, we hosted a total of 28 students (chosen from a competitive national applicant pool of approximately 400 students each summer), in addition to a several Fairfield University summer mathematics students who were working with Fairfield faculty under other grant funding. Each summer of the program has an eight week duration, during which time students work together in small groups (typically, three to four students per group) under the direct supervision and mentorship of a Fairfield faculty member on research projects designed by the mentor.

The primary goals of the program are to broaden the base of scientific participation at the national level and to help prepare our participants for the professional demands of pursuing advanced careers in mathematics or other scientific disciplines. A secondary goal is the advancement of the discipline through the student research work. The vast majority of our students either elect to continue in graduate study after participating in our program, or else conclude based on their experience that advanced study is not in their interests, and we consider both of these outcomes to be successful ones. In addition to successful recruiting efforts aimed at including more women in the STEM fields, our program has also hosted several LGBTQ students over the past three years. 

Our students always report out the results of their summer work in a variety of settings. The majority of our research groups have produced or are producing journal submissions of peer-review quality, and all of our students typically attend and present at the National Meetings of the American Mathematical Society and the Mathematical Association of America (in the latter category, our students have won multiple awards for the content of their presentations).
